arm_group.description: The Functional Electrical Stimulation (FES) group will be asked to use their clinically prescribed FES unit (either ODFS III or Pace) to the dorsiflexors to treat foot drop for a period of 12 weeks.
The people in the Ankle Foot Orthosis group (AFO) will be asked to use their clinically prescribed AFO to treat drop foot for a period of 12 weeks.

brief_summary.textblock:
This investigation consists of two parallel groups of participants who will follow the same
      protocol. The aim of the study is to investigate the effects of using Functional Electrical
      Stimulation/Ankle Foot Orthosis (AFO) or splint as an assistive mobility device over a 12
      week period in people with MS who experience foot drop. Patients who are clinically
      prescribed FES will be invited to participate in the FES arm of the study. Patients who are
      clinically prescribed an AFO will be invited to participate in the AFO arm. Participants
      will be asked to make four visits to the gait laboratory at Queen Margaret University. Four
      weeks before the start of device use (Baseline - 4 weeks), start of device use (Baseline),
      after 6 weeks and 12 weeks of device use. Participants' walking will assessed using
      computerised three dimensional motion analysis, which will provide a detailed description of
      the movements (kinematics) of the lower limbs. Participants will also be asked to carry out
      a 10 metre walk and a two minute walk. Both gait analysis and the walking performance tests
      will be carried out with and without an assistive device; apart from their first session
      where participants will only be assessed without their assistive device.

      Participants will be asked to wear an activity monitor for 7 days after each assessment. In
      addition participants will be asked to complete four short standardised questionnaires (MS
      walking scale, MS impact scale (MSIS-29), Fatigue severity score and the Leeds MS Quality of
      life score) at each assessment.

clinical_study.brief_title: Walking With FES or AFO in People With MS With Foot Drop

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  People diagnosed with Multiple Sclerosis

          -  Prescribed either AFO or FES to treat drop foot by their physiotherapist

          -  aged 18-75

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Unable to walk 10 meters

          -  Bilateral device use

          -  Breastfeeding or pregnant

study_pop.textblock:
People with Multiple Sclerosis who have been prescribed either FES or an AFO to treat foot
        drop by their physiotherapist.

investigator.last_name: Marietta L van der Linden, PhD

clinical_study.official_title: A Pilot Study to Assess the Effects of Using FES or AFO as an Assistive Mobility for Period of 12 Weeks for People With Multiple Sclerosis With Foot Drop

other_outcome.description: During the 2 minute walk test the participant walks around an oval shaped track for 2 minutes. The distance covered in two minutes is taken for analysis.
other_outcome.measure: change in distance covered in two minutes
other_outcome.time_frame: The change from baseline in the the 2 minute walk test at 12 weeks.

other_outcome.measure: The change in the MS walking scale (MSWS)
other_outcome.time_frame: The change from baseline in the MSWS at 12 weeks

other_outcome.measure: the change in the MS impact scale (MSIS29)
other_outcome.time_frame: The change from basline in the MSIS29 at 12 weeks

other_outcome.measure: The change in the Fatigue Severity Score (FSS)
other_outcome.time_frame: The change from baseline in the FSS at 12 weeks

other_outcome.measure: The change in the Leeds MS Quality of Life score (LMSQoL)
other_outcome.time_frame: The change from baseline in the LMSQoL at 12 weeks

overall_contact.last_name: Marietta L van der Linden, PhD

overall_official.last_name: Marietta L van der Linden, PhD

primary_outcome.description: In the 10 meter walk test, the time taken by the participant to walk 10 meters is recorded. The test is repeated and the average is taken for analysis.
primary_outcome.measure: Change in time taken for 10 meter walk test
primary_outcome.time_frame: change from baseline in 10m walk test at 12 weeks

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.description: The ankle dorsiflexion angle is derived from gait analysis. The angle of the ankle at the time the foot contacts the floor during a step is derived. This is repeated for at least 5 different walks, and the average of those 5 walks is calculated for further analysis.
secondary_outcome.measure: Change in ankle dorsiflexion angle at initial contact
secondary_outcome.time_frame: The change from baseline of the ankle dorsiflexion angle at initial contact from at 12 weeks

clinical_study.study_design: Observational Model: Case Control, Time Perspective: Prospective
